images.altText: Magnified immune cells in a cluster formation

pageData.text: DNA is the fundamental template for all proteins and, ultimately, all life. This exercise uses a simple procedure to isolate and extract DNA from commonly available fruits. Chromosomal DNA is isolated and precipitated in cold ethanol, allowing DNA to be visualized.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: 1-inch cube of banana or kiwi, or one small strawberry
Bottled spring water or distilled water

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 10 minutes 
Activity 1: Fruit DNA Extraction - 45 minutes
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 10 minutes 
Activity 1: Fruit DNA Extraction - 45 minutes

pageData.subTitle: OverView Video: DNA Extraction from Fruit

text: Describe the function, structure, and location of DNA.
Explain the importance of DNA extraction and how it pertains to everyday life.
Perform a DNA extraction from plant cells of a fruit.
Observe and identify DNA extracted from plant cells.

pageData.text: One reason that fruit is commonly used for DNA extraction is that most commercially available fruit is polyploid. This means that the fruit has multiple copies of the same chromosomes. Humans and most other organisms are diploid meaning that they have two copies of every chromosome. Most strawberries found in a grocery store, on the other hand, are octoploid meaning that they have eight copies of every chromosome. This polyploidy can occur when chromosomes fail to separate during meiosis, called nondisjunction, creating gametes with more chromosomes than usual. Most of the time, this gamete or the offspring created is not viable or has serious complications, but in rare cases, the polyploid survives creating a new species. In plants that produce fruit, like the strawberry, polyploidy happens relatively frequently and can even represent the merger of two different, but closely related species. One reason for this is that polyploid fruits tend to be larger and more robust than the original species. Humans can even intentionally breed polyploid crops to create new varieties of fruit producing plants<sup>1</sup>.

1Sattler, M. C., Carvalho, C. R., & Clarindo, W. R. (2016). The polyploidy and its key role in plant breeding. Planta, 243(2), 281–296.
https://doi.org/10.1007/s00425-015-2450-x

pageData.subTitle: DNA Function
pageData.text: Living organisms are composed of complex mixtures of chemicals that come in a myriad of forms and perform an amazing number of functions. Just as all computer programs are ultimately controlled by a series of ones and zeros, all life on earth is controlled by a series of four molecules called <button class='glossary-text'>nucleic acids</button>. A group of nucleic acids which are bound together on a backbone of sugar and phosphate groups create DNA. DNA sequences code for proteins, which facilitate most cellular functions in living organisms. By controlling the production and concentrations of proteins, DNA controls the development of complex organisms. In addition, DNA provides a mechanism through which traits can be passed from one generation to the next.

Because of the vital roles that DNA plays in all of life’s processes, it is important that DNA is protected from damage or alteration. DNA is vulnerable to damage from ultraviolet radiation and mutagens, such as ozone and heavy metals. Viruses can also insert foreign genetic material into the DNA of host cells, disrupting their function. Plant cells have developed a number of strategies for protecting their genetic material from harm.

The <button class='glossary-text'>cell membrane</button> protects the fragile DNA molecules from damage. In eukaryotic cells, DNA is also protected by the <button class='glossary-text'>nuclear membrane</button>, which consists of a double layer of phospholipids, lipids containing phosphate groups. Plant cells have a <button class='glossary-text'>cell wall</button> in addition to the cell membrane, which acts as extra protection to these cells. Both of these barriers must be broken in order to extract DNA from a plant cell.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A typical eukaryotic plant cell labeled with the major organelles and other cell components.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A typical eukaryotic plant cell labeled with the major organelles and other cell components.

pageData.subTitle: DNA Structure
pageData.text: The basic structure of DNA resembles a twisted ladder or double helix. The backbone of the ladder is comprised of deoxyribose sugars alternating with phosphate groups. Attached to each sugar molecule is a nitrogenous base, either guanine (G), adenine (A), thymine (T), or cytosine (C). Each base is paired with a complementary base on the opposite strand; these base pairs are bound together by a hydrogen bond. These bonds make up the “rungs” of the ladder (Figure 2).

pageData.subTitle: Packaging DNA
pageData.text: The length of DNA in each cell is about 100,000 times that of the cell itself. However, DNA comprises only about 10% of the cell volume. This is because DNA is tightly packaged through a series of events that allow it to fit easily into the cell nucleus (Figure 2).

To condense DNA, the double helix wraps itself around groups of proteins called <button class='glossary-text'>histones</button>. Histones wrapped with DNA look like beads on a string. This DNA-histone complex is called <button class='glossary-text'>chromatin</button>, and the bead-like regions are called <button class='glossary-text'>nucleosomes</button>. Chromatin folds back on itself, and the nucleosomes pack together, creating a compact, protein-coated fiber.

The fiber coils and is further reduced in size into an extended chromosome. In its most compressed state, this coiled fiber organizes into loops emanating from a central axis (scaffold) to create a condensed, X-shaped chromosome (Figure 2).

pageData.desc: Figure 2: DNA helix creating a condensed, x-shaped chromosome
pageData.altText: Figure 2: DNA helix creating a condensed, x-shaped chromosome

pageData.text: Chromosomal DNA from a single cell is invisible to the naked eye. However, when DNA is extracted from multiple cells, the amassed material can be easily seen and has the appearance of strands of mucus-like, translucent cotton. This DNA is coated with proteins and may be at various stages of condensation (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button>). Individual, condensed chromosomes can be observed by light microscopy. However, the double helix is only a few nanometers wide and can only be detected with sophisticated imaging techniques, such as scanning probe microscopy.

pageData.question: What is the total cell volume that DNA comprises?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: DNA comprises about 10% of the cell volume.

pageData.question: In order for the extraordinary amount of DNA in a cell to fit within the nucleus, DNA condenses into which of the following structures?

options.text: DNA is wrapped around proteins, which structure is then folded on itself.
DNA is folded into pleats and then coiled into helices.
DNA is wrapped around proteins extending from the nuclear membrane.
DNA is encapsulated in a protein coat.
DNA is stacked on itself with proteins between each layer.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: DNA is wrapped around proteins (histones) to form chromatin, which is then folded back on itself.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The length of DNA in each cell is about 100,000 times that of the cell itself; however, DNA comprises only 10% of the cell’s total volume. DNA is tightly packaged through a series of events that allow it to fit easily into the cell nucleus. To condense DNA, the double helix wraps itself around groups of proteins called histones.  This DNA-histone complex is called chromatin, and the bead-like regions are called nucleosomes. Chromatin folds back on itself, and the nucleosomes pack together, creating a compact, protein-coated fiber. The fiber coils and is further reduced in size into an extended chromosome. In its most compressed state, this coiled fiber organizes into loops emanating from a central axis (scaffold) to create a condensed, X-shaped chromosome.

pageData.subTitle: DNA Extraction from Fruit
pageData.text: In order to extract chromosomal DNA from plant cells, such as those in a banana, the <button class='glossary-text'>cell wall</button> and the cellular and <button class='glossary-text'>nuclear membranes</button> must first be broken through a process called <button class='glossary-text'>cell lysis</button>. The cell wall can be broken by physical methods, such as mashing or blending. Once the cell wall is broken, the membranes that surround the cell and nucleus must be disrupted. These membranes act as barriers to protect and separate the cell, nucleus, and DNA from the surrounding environment. Cellular and nuclear membranes are composed of two layers of phospholipids, which is called a <button class='glossary-text'>phospholipid bilayer</button>. To lyse cells in a test tube, the cellular and nuclear membranes are disrupted with a detergent and salt-based lysis solution. Just as a dishwashing detergent must dissolve fats (lipids) to clean a frying pan, a detergent-based cell lysis solution dissolves the <button class='glossary-text'>phospholipid bilayer</button> of <button class='glossary-text'>cell membranes</button> by forming water-soluble complexes with the lipids. Once the cell membranes have been disrupted, the cellular contents flow out and create a “soup” of dissolved membranes, cellular proteins, DNA, and other molecules. This “soup” is called the <button class='glossary-text'>cell lysate</button>.

The DNA in the cell lysate is in solution. When ethanol contacts the cell lysate, it causes the DNA to precipitate or come out of solution. This forms a translucent cloud of fine, stringy fibers at the ethanol-cell lysate interface. Cold ethanol precipitates DNA most effectively. DNA is negatively charged due to the phosphate ions on its backbone. The salinity of the lysis solution neutralizes this negative charge by coating the DNA with positively charged sodium ions. This counteracts the mutual repulsion of the DNA strands, allowing them to clump together as they precipitate.

It is important to remember that extracted DNA from fruit represents a huge collection of chromosomes (many strands of DNA) that are clustered together and isolated from a large quantity of cells. This DNA is folded and condensed around protein molecules. The DNA extract is considered to be crude, because it has not been separated from the cellular proteins that adhere to it during precipitation.

pageData.subTitle: Importance of DNA Extraction
pageData.text: The principles of DNA extraction used in this activity apply to procedures used by scientists to extract DNA from many different sources. DNA extraction is a fundamental procedure in scientific laboratories around the world and is often the first step in many in-depth laboratory experiments. By extracting and analyzing DNA, scientists can learn how DNA encodes instructions for all of the processes of life. DNA extraction and analysis are also important in basic research, such as the investigation of mechanisms underlying heredity and agricultural science to help develop crops with higher yields that are more resistant to disease and drought.

pageData.question: In this activity, which of the following steps will you take to break down the cell walls of your plant sample?

options.text: by mashing or blending the sample
by a detergent to the sample
by exposing the sample to UV radiation
by a salt-based lysis solution to the sample
by incubating the sample in the freezer

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The cell wall can be broken by physical methods, such as mashing or blending.

pageData.question: Once the cell membranes have been disrupted during the extraction protocol, where will the DNA be?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Once the cell membranes have been disrupted, the DNA is in the cell lysate solution.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, create DNA extraction buffer, then mash a fruit sample, and mix the buffer and fruit sample together. Next, filter out the solids from the mixture, and layer ethanol onto the filtrate. Allow the layers to incubate for 15 minutes. Finally, observe and isolate the DNA precipitate.

pageData.text: Reorder Information:Replacement supplies for DNA Extraction from Fruit, item number 580170, can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Wear your safety goggles and gloves at all times while conducting this investigation.

Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE), as described in the Safety and Procedure Section.
Ethanol is flammable. Keep this chemical away from all flames and heat sources.
Ethanol is denatured and is very harmful if swallowed.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum during this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following are bound together on a backbone of sugar and phosphate groups to form DNA?
DNA is condensed so that it may be tightly packaged within the cell nucleus. Which of the following does the double helix wrap itself around?
When a phospholipid bilayer has been disrupted, the cell contents flow out and create a “soup” of dissolved membranes, cellular proteins, DNA and other molecules.  What is the “soup” called?
Which of the following is unique to plant cells and provides them with extra protection?
Which of the following statements about DNA precipitation is correct?

options.text: When DNA precipitates, it comes out of solution.
Hot ethanol is more effective than cold ethanol in precipitating DNA.
The lysis solution does not require salt for DNA precipitation.
DNA precipitation takes place when the DNA is negatively charged.
DNA precipitation is only visible with a microscope.

Which of the following safety hazards is associated with the ethanol provided in your kit for this investigation?

options.text: It may stain skin or clothing.
It is extremely harmful to aquatic life.

adding a drop of liquid detergent
precipitating and filtering out with hot ethanol

Read through the activity.

typeBefore.text: Chill the 70% ethanol by storing it in a freezer or in a container of ice until ready for use in step 10 of the activity. Needs to be ice cold before use.

pageData.text: Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.

In Activity 1, you will mix a fruit of your choice with DNA extraction buffer and filter to create a fruit filtrate. You will then separate the DNA from the lysed cells using ethanol and observe the quantity and macrostructure of the extracted DNA.

To prepare the extraction buffer, measure 10 mL of detergent with the 25-mL graduated cylinder. Pour 190 mL of water, the detergent, and half of the contents of the salt packet into a beaker. Stir to mix.
Place the fruit in the sealable plastic bag.
Close the bag, pushing all of the air out of the bag as you seal it.
Being careful not to break the bag, mash the fruit with your hands for two minutes.
Using the 25-mL graduated cylinder, pour 10 mL of the extraction buffer (made in step 1) into the bag. Reseal the bag.
Mash the fruit for one additional minute.
Place the funnel into the 25-mL graduated cylinder. Fold the cheesecloth in half, cut it in half, and place it in the funnel to create a filter.
Pour the fruit mixture into the funnel. Note: If the fruit mixture is not filtering through the cheesecloth very easily, use your gloved hands to “mash” the mixture to help facilitate the process.
When the fruit mixture has been filtered, carefully pour 2 mL of the filtered solution into the 15-mL tube.
Remove the ethanol from the freezer or ice container.
Remove the cap from the tube.

Hold the 15-mL tube at an angle. Use a plastic pipet to carefully add cold, 70% ethanol to the tube by running it down the inside wall of the tube. Add the ethanol until the total volume inside the tube reaches 12–13 mL. (Use the lines on the side of the tube for measurement. You can place the cap back on the tube.)

The exact amount of ethanol is not important. What is important is that the ethanol is carefully layered on top of the lysis solution. There should be two distinct layers. Do not mix the lysate layer with the ethanol layer (Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: DNA becoming visible between cell lysate layer and ethanol layer
pageData.altText: Figure 3: DNA becoming visible between cell lysate layer and ethanol layer

pageData.text: Watch closely as wispy strands of translucent DNA begin to clump together where the ethanol layer meets the <button class='glossary-text'>cell lysate</button> layer (Figure 3).
Place the 15-mL tube upright in the cup, and let it stand undisturbed for a minimum of 10 minutes. Do not shake or disturb the tube.

Use the wooden applicator stick to gently spool the DNA from the uppermost end of the most extended strand in the ethanol layer. The DNA should be drawn up as one strand. Do not move the stick tip down into the cell lysate layer. Observe the DNA on the tip.

text: Pour the remaining mash, <button class='glossary-text'>cell lysis</button> buffer, and ethanol down the drain, and follow with excess tap water.
Discard any used pipets and tubes in household trash.
Put all remaining supplies back in the lab box.
Clean your work area with a household surface cleaner.

text: Why should the ethanol/lysate boundary not be disturbed?
Do you think we can use a blender to break open the cells to isolate the DNA? Why or why not?

Some plants’ cells have a hard, cellulose layer protecting them.  This hardened layer will prevent the detergent from breaking down the cell wall.  Can you think of another way to break open the cells?
Why do we need to filter the mash with the cheese cloth?

A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, create DNA extraction buffer, then mash a fruit sample, and mix the buffer and fruit sample together. Next, filter out the solids from the mixture, and layer ethanol onto the filtrate. Allow the layers to incubate for 15 minutes. Finally, observe and isolate the DNA precipitate.
Figure 3: DNA becoming visible between cell lysate layer and ethanol layer

data.title: Cell lysate
data.content: A mixture of dissolved membranes, cellular proteins, DNA, and other molecules that exude from damage to the plasma membrane

data.title: Cell lysis
data.content: The breakage of the plasma membrane, or the cell wall, and leakage of cellular contents

data.title: Cell membrane
data.content: The membraneous structure that separates the intracellular components from the extracellular space, and allows transport in and out of cell

data.title: Cell wall
data.content: The structure surrounding some cells that provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment

data.title: Histone
data.content: Any of a group of basic proteins found in chromatin

data.title: Nuclear membrane
data.content: A phospholipid bilayer that separates the contents of the nucleus from the rest of the cell

data.title: Nucleic acid
data.content: A class of biological macromolecule; molecules are composed of monomers called nucleotides; examples include doxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA)

data.title: Nucleosomes
data.content: The smallest structural component of chromatin; it is produced through interactions between DNA and histone proteins

data.title: Phospholipid bilayer
data.content: The structure of the two layers of phospholipids that make up cell membranes, with the hydrophilic heads toward the inner and outer environments, and the hydrophobic tails sandwiched in between
